div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, JUNE 25, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular three-weekly Service from HAMBURG, via ANTWERP & MALTA, to ALEXANDRIA and vice-versa, admitting goods from all chief German Railway Stations on direct Bill of Landing to ALEXANDRIA and all chief ports of Egypt, Syria, etc., at favourable through rates of DEUTSCHE VERKEHR (traffic).
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. Lesbos July 20 from Antwerp.
S.S. Androos July 20 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.
S.S. Lemnos July 31 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves for Jeddah continuing every other week for Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate Steamers do not proceed at Jeddah but call at Tor (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8:30 a.m. in time for express to Switzerland, Paris and London leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11:20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday attached to Express leaving Cairo 9:30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 20 June, 4 and 18 July, 1 and 15 August.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 18 June, 2, 16, and 30 July, 13 August.

To Suez, Aden, Karachi and Bombay about 13 Mar., 13 Apr., 13 Nov., 13 Dec.(Winter Line).

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: CAIRO-KHARTOUM SUMMER MAIL SERVICE.
Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice.

*Sleeping and Dining Cars. - During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Cars trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays, and Saturdays at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays, and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1906, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Cars will be attached to the ordinary night trains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days.

div.head: Thos. Cook & Son, (EGYPT), LTD
div.p: HEAD OFFICE: LUDGATE CIRCUS, LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE: — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, and Halfa.
TOURIST AND GENERAL PASSENGER AGENTS, BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for imformation respecting their passages, where steamer plans may be consulted, and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.
CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe.
Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at principal Railway Stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their tickets.

Large splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Company leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan, and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT; Lowest rates.
Best camp equipment in the country.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
Moon rises 7.55 a.m.
sets 9.43 p.m.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: A clear sky, a moderate breeze, and a warm sun were the conditions yesterday. To-day, too, the morning opens with a moderate beeze from N.W. and a falling barometer.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, ROWLAND SNELLING, Alexandria.
London Correspondent's Offices--36, New Broad-street. E.C.
Offices.--No. 1 Sharia Zervudaehl, (opposite Agricultural Bank)
The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
MONDAY, JUNE 25, 1906.

div.head: THE STATE OF RUSSIA.
div.p: The news received from Russia during the last few days is hardly likely to encourage the partisans of a Russian alliance. The cruel massacre of Jews at Bielostok, the peasant outbreaks in several provinces, the revival of the strikes in St. Petersburg, and the continuance of insubordination in the Black Sea fleet, show conclusively that the concessions hitherto extored from the Government will not satisfy the mujiks, much less the revolutionary organisations. The Duma, which complains of the dilatory methods of officialism, is itself criticised by the insurgent peasants for its incapcacity to effect an instant change in the conditions of their tenure, and the naive villager, who in his simplicity imagines that the whole land system of Russia can be remodelled in a fortnight, chafes against the delays caused by the limitation of the powers of his representatives. The disclosures of Prince Urusoff have, of course horrified the Duma and the intelligent members of the Russian public but whether they were entirely wise from the patriotic point of view is highly doubtful. The one chance for Russia, the one possibility of avoiding a period of anarchy and revolution that may last for a generation, is a working agreement between the remains of the autocracy and the Constitutional Democrats of Duma. Should this be rendered impossible by the folly of the autocrcy or by the indiscretion of members of the assembly nothing can save Russia from being reduced to importence. The overthrow of the autocracy could only lead to a victory of the extremis forces, the Jacobins of the Russian reign of terror, whose subversive ideals are hardly likely to prove efficient in aught but destruction. The Constitutional Democrats, the conservative element both among peasants and land owners, would alike fall victims to a revolutionary town proletariat organised and led by the apostles of anarchy, and if thedemands and actions of the revolutionary party furnish any clue to their policy we may expect them to aim at a very extreme form of revolutionary Socialism. The alternative is military despoism with General Trepoff at the helm. Metternich's dictum that one can do anything with bayonets but sit on them condemns any such regime in advance.

As far as one can judge there are five parties in Russia proper which count. The old guard of autocracy, powerless for the moment to attract support, but still capable of playing off one party against another; the peasants easily roused to fury against Cossacks, or Jews, tax collectors, or "intelligents," childisly ignorant and incapable, for the present, of that combination that would lead their enormous numbers to certain victory, the various revolutionary groups whose programmes are rigidly Socialist or frankly Anarchist, but which agree in aiming at the utter overthrow of the Bureacracy, the Church, and the Tsardom, and in drawing for support upon the poorer Jew and the industrial population of the great cities; the constitutional party, with all its subdivisions, that desire the establishment in one form or another of a constitutional Government upon British or French lines; and lastly, the Separatist sections -- united in a common desire to throw off the Russian yoke once and for all and whose hopes may yet be gratified should the threatened Revolution sweep away the Tsardom and convert the army into a national guard. A third of the Poles, a great majority of the Finns, Georgians, Armenians, and Moslems of Central Asia and the Caucasus form this gropu. Should the autocracy sink in blood we may yet see a Polish republic, an independent Georgia, and Transcaucasia, its Armenians overthrown, won back by the armies of the Sultan. As for the ruin of thousands of French investors and the bankruptcy of the Empire, nothing, unhappily, seems more probable.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL CAIRO.
div.p:
Built In 1904. Modern House. Splendid situation. Eectric Light
Lift, Pension P.T. 50. Arrangements for families.
Rooms and Breakfast P.T. 25.— Meals a la Cart

div.head: THE DENISHWAI AFFAIR
TRIAL OF ACCUSED
DESCRIPTION OF THE COURT
div.p: On arriving at Chibin el Kom at half past three this afternoon, one of my first duties was to call upon the mourdir, Mohmoud Bey Shoncri, and to receive the ticket which would admit me to the special tables which have been reserved for members of the press for the trial of the villagers who are accused of unprovokedly attacking British officers at Denishwai on the 13th inst., as has already been related in the "Egyptian Gazette." The trial will be held in a large marquee, which has been erected in the inner court of the mondirieh, and only those holding tickets will be admitted. The preparations fot the trial, which have been made under the direction of the Ministry of the Interior, are excellent. At one end of the tent a platform has been erected, which is destined for the members of the special tribunal. At each side of, and at right angles to this platform are the "docks," in which the accused will be placed, and directly in front of these are the tables for the representatives of the Press, forming three sides of a square, within which are the seats for thsoe directly concerned in the trial, including the officers of the Army of Occupation who will be present. Beyone the Press tables are several rows of seats for thsoe who have obtained tickets for the trial.

On the east bank of the canal which runs past Chibin el Kom the British troops, consisting of a company of Mounted Infantry, a detachment of the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons,, dismounted, and forty Military Mounted Police are encamped. Mr. Machell, who returned here yesterday and will remain until the end of the trial, is staying on board the deliabieh Scout. Moberly Bey returned to Chibin this evening from Denishwai, where he has spent the whole of to-day collecting evidence.

div.head: Excitement at Chibin
div.p: At ten minutes past seven Judge Bond, Lt. Col. E. R. Ludlow, and Major Pine Coffin arrived from Cairo and were met by a detachment of the Military Mounted Police. Considerable excitememt was caused by their arrival. From the moment that the detachment of Mounted Police arrived at the station the villagers in the vicinity collected in considerable numbers, and when the train drew up at the platform there must have been between three and four hundred lining the approach to the station. The party was met at the station by Mahmoud Bey Shoucri. It will interest your readers to learn that every comfort for the members of the Court, including Osman Bey Mortada, greffier, has been arranged for by the Military of the Interior, who have placed rooms at their disposal in the mondirieh.

For the moment, I can give you no further news. The commencement of the trial to-morrow morning is awaited here with great interest, especially by the large number of Press representatives who have arrived. Speculation as to the results of the trial is rife both here and in Cairo, and, indeed, probably throughout Egypt. To anticipate the verdict, to assent that such and such sentences will be passed, or that the accused will be liberated without punishment, is exceedingly foolish and absolutely futile. That justice will be meted out to the offenders is the desire of all, and the constitution of the special tribunal may be considered as a guarantee of the right course being taken. The scoused have been provided with most able lawyers for their defence and it cannot be doubted that the decision of the Court, wahtever it may be, will be in accordance with the evidence and, therefore, just.

div.head: Duration of Trial
div.p: I cannot say how long the trial will last, as it is impossible to discover what course the proceedings will take, in so far as the defence is concerned. It is possible that two days may suffice, but on the other hand, it may spread over three or four days.

div.head: COMMENCEMENT OF TRIAL
EVIDENCE OF OFFICERS
div.p: The special tribunal, under the presidency of Boutros Pacha Ghali, commenced its sittings at ten o'clock this morning and adjourned at 1 p.m. for an interval of three hours. Sometime before the trial commenced a considerable crowd collected in the vicinity of the moudirieh, but admirable oder was kept by the police. When I entered the tent shortly after nine o'clock nearly every seat was occupied and the tables reserved for the Press were crowded with Special Correspondents, of whom there were over forty.

At ten minutes to ten the fifty-two men who have been arrested were brought into Court and placed in the docks, which face each other. The charge also includes seven others who have not been found. Each prisoner carried round his neck a large card bearing the number under which he is entered on the charge sheet. The accused varied in age considerably, some being but youths, of 18 or 19, and others old men, but all were coarse-featured, uneducated sons of the soil. A few minutes after ten the members o the tribunal took their seats; after which the names of the accused were called out, and the general charge was read by the Secretary to the Court, Osman Bey Mortada, in which the events of the 13th inst., as revealed by the preliminary enquiry, were related in Arabic and the prisoners were charged with taking part therein.

The three lawyers for the defence, Maltres Ahmed Bey Yousef, Ismain Bey Assem, and Mohamed Bey Yousef, then informed the Court which of the prisoners each represented, and Bontros Pacha Ghali commenced to ask each individual what answer he desired to make to the charge, whether he pleaded "guilty" or "not guilty." This was to be done according to the numbering of the prisoners, but it was found that the numbers had been chagned. As considerable in-convenience would be caused throughout the trial by the numbers not coinciding with the names of the prisoners, the President of the Tribunal ordered them to be re-changed and the tribunal left the Court until this was done, a delay of half-an-hour being caused by the contretemps.

On the return of the tribunal the prisoners were charged individually, and all pleaded "not guilty." Various reasons and denials were given. Some were in their houses that morning, others were not in the vilage, a few of the mean pleaded that they were ill and not on the scene at all, and several merely said they had done nothing.

The first witness for the prosecution was Major Pine Coffin, who came into Court with his arm in a sling and limping slightly, and he was allowed to sit while he gave his evidence. Witness deposed that on Wednesday, the 13th inst., he went out to shoot pigeons near the village of Denishwai in cmopany with four other officers. They rode from the camp on horseback for a short distance, after which they met a carriage which had been sent for them by some perosn. When they got near the village they got out of their carriage and walked along the road where they met a man wearing a blue galabieh and red slippers and accompanied by four or five fellaheen, whom witness took to represent the omdeh. The onbashi of the police, who accompanied them, had been sent on in front to ask permission of the omdeh for the officers to shoot pigeons.
Questioned by Lt. Col. E. R. Ludlow, Major Pine-Coffin said that all the officers were in khaki uniform, wearing knee- breeches and spurs and helmets, and all wore their regimental shoulder badges.

Major Pine-Coffin was then asked by Mr. Hayter if he could identify this man from among the prisoners in the docks, and the witness pointed out as an old man, prisoner No. 11, as being the man whom he met on the road. Continuing, witness said that when he went out pigeon shooting he always obtained beforehand the permission of the omdeh of the village. Not being able to speak Arabic, witness told his guide, Abdul, ot ask the manif they might shoot pigeons. the man said "Yes," but told Abdul that they must go far back from the village. Witness pointed out some trees and asked, through his guide, if that was far enough away, and was told that it was. Having received permission to shoot, witness, Capt. Baull, and Lieut. Smithwick went off to the trees, while Capt. Bostock and Lieut. Porter went to the south-east of the village. A map was then shown Major Pine-Coffin, who pointed out the positions which they took up.

Continuing, witness said that he sent the guide to the other two officers to see if they were far enough away from the village and that everything was in order. Of the party at the trees Major Pine-Coffin was in the middle, with Capt. Bull on his left and Lieut. Smithwick on his right. Witness fired one shot at a pigeon and then turning round henoticed that Capt. Bull was trying to charge his gun. This man had been given charge of Capt. Bull's cartridge bag to carry for him.

Witness then hurried towards the officers who were on the other side and saw that the men became more excited because they saw smoke issuing form a spot near the village. Very shortly afterwards Abdul, the guide, came running back and was very excited. He said that something was on fire and that the other officers were being mobbed. Witness went across the road, followed by Capt. Bull and Lieut. Smithwick. He did not know about the fire except from seeing the smoke. As they went towards Capt. Bostock and Lieut. Porter to help them they were followed by the natives. On their arrival at the scene witness asked what was the matter and was told by Lieut. Porter that his gun had been taken from him and had gone off accidentally, and that he thought a woman had been shot. Witness understood, at the time, that the woman was dead, and realising that Lieut. Porter's position was serious he desired to get the officers away without trouble.

Witness, who had not been attacked personally up to this point, gave up his gun and desired the other officers to do the same. He then told Lieut. Porter that he had killed a woman and that he must take him away, and would, therefore, arrest him. Intimating this to the crowd he took Lieut. Porter by the neck and commenced to march him off. Capt. Bull and Lieut. Smithwick were behind him, but he did not see the former. Starting towards the carriages they were surrounded on the right and left sides and in the rear by fellaheen, but he could not say that there were any in front of them.

At this point witness was asked to identify from among the fifty-two prisoners those whom he knew to have formed past of the crowd. Of these he recognised 29, stating that he was not prepared to swear that they all took part in the attack, but was confident that they were present.

Prisoner No. 28, Mohamed Darous Azwan, was, said witness, the ringleader of the mob, which he urged on with great energy, but he could not say if he carried a stick. In identifying prisoner No. 9 witness remarked that he believed him to have taken the part of the officers. Witness was informed that No. 28 said he had given him (the witness) water and that the latter had offered him his watch and a bakshish. Witness said that he had offered his watch to show that he would pay for any damage that was done and to try to pacify them. Prisoner did not take the watch. It was pointed out to witness that at the inquiry he did not recognise Nos. 4, 25, and 13, but that he did so now. Witness stated that, as he had sadi before, he could not swear to them, but that he spoke to the best of his belief.

At the time that they started for the carriage all the officers were fairly near together. They were all within an area of about fifty yards and he was escorting Lieut. Porter. When they got about half-way to the carriage a man struck witness from behind on the head and he was knocked senseless, and had no recollection of what happened afterwards until he regained consciousness. He lost consciousness three times. The next thing that he remembered was that they were going along the road followed by a crowd of fellaheen with sticks who were throwing mud. Capt. Bull and Capt. Bostock were on the road and were pursued by natives with nabouts and he shouted to them to get back fo camp. Witness's helmet was knocked off his head early in the attack and he lost his watch, medeal ribbon and brooch, and cartridges, and his coat was ripped up. Being knocked senseless a second time witness recovered consciousness to find a man hittin ghis arm with a nabout and he felt that it was broken. He saw that Lieuts. Porter and Smithwick were with him, while Capts. Bull and Bostock were well ahead.

The natives dragged witness and Lieuts. Porter and Smithwick back towards the village, witness only being semi conscious. They were made to sit down and Lieut. Porter said, "Oh, they are going to burn us." Witness regained full consciousness when the onbashi of police returned and gave him water. There were probably people helping them and these would probably have taken their part before but dared not. The man whom witness had taken to represent the omdeh was, he believed, the same man who met him last year. He had no reason to believe that the guide misinterpreted what this man said.
At this point the Court rose, and did not meet again till four o'clock.
Major Pine-Coffin was recalled and counsel for the defence were asked if they wished to ask any questions.

In answer to Ismain Bey Assem, witness said that the man to whom he offered his watch was among the crowd but he could not say what his intentions were. He gave the watch as a payment for the burned tibn, and not as a reward for services rendered.

In answer to Mohamed Bey Youssef he said that the four men whom they met were on the road when they got out of the carriages and that he did not recognise any of them among the prisoners except No. 11, whom he took to represent the omdeh. The man who held the cartridges and the one who told them where to go were of this party. The only previous notice these men had that the officers of the party wished to go shooting was that given by the onbashi of police when he went to inform the omdeh.

Counsel pointed out that three persons, other than the woman, were found wounded. "Did witness know of this?" "No, he only knew that they woman was wounded and he believed her to be dead,:" as told him by Lieut. Porter. Witness always understood that wild pigeons, such as they were shooting at, were public property when they were outside the bounds of the village.

Before retiring, Major Pine-Coffin asked to be allowed to say that he had marched through the country for three years and had always been received with every respect by the omdehs and notabilities of the villages. On his aprt he was alwasy kind to the natives and never had any ill feeling against them.

Lieut. Smithwick, who was called as next witness, said that ongetting out of the carriage he wwent to the extreme right. After firing two shots he saw the guide beckoning excitedly to him and he went along the road towards the other party, Major Pine Coffin and Capt. Bull having already gone. When he got within 50 or 60 yards of the crowd he heard a muffled report and saw the people surge back. He saw Lieut. Porter standing there and a man with his gun in his hand. He saw nobody lying wounded. He also saw that Lieut. Porter was being handled roughly and Major Pine-Coffin take hold of him, by the arm, and when he got up to them he was told to take the other arm. He did not understand, but thought the idea was to arrest Lieut. Porter. Major Pine-Coffin told him to give up his gun, and as he did so it was snatched from him. Mohamed Darous Azwan, prisoner No. 48, appeared to witness to be one of the leaders of the mob. They were joined by Capts. Bull and Bostock, and on reaching the carriages the other four officers got in and he mounted his horse and rode away. Turning round he saw that those in the carriage were being pulled out and he returned but was pulled off his horse. Someone shouted for them to run, and they all started together, Capts. Bull and Bostock leading.

After he had gone a short way he saw Major Pine-Coffin lying on the ground with his face downwards and a native on top of him. He pulled the man off, and identified prisoner No. 24 as being the man. Witness saw Capt. Bull struck twice with half a brick on the side, back, and head. Capt. Bull staggered, dazed, and bleeding profusely. Witness himself was struck with a brick on the face and on the back and neck by a nabout. The fellaheen dragged them back towards the village and threw them on the ground, kicking them to make them rise. Witness was unconscious. He saw Major Pine-Coffin hit twice and identified one man in the crowd who proposed to cut their throats were made to sit on the threshing floor surrounded by heaps of tibn as if they meand to burn them. Witness recognised witness No. 9, whom he believed to be friendly.

Capt. Bostock, who was next called deposed that he was with Lieut Porter about 300 yards from the village and 100 yards from the tibn. After nine shots had been fired people gathered round and a fire broke out which lasted two minutes. He tried to reach the carriage by offering bakshish. He managed to reach the road and was beaten continuously. He saw Capt. Bull struck and bleeding and pulled from the carriage, while they were beating him severely. When the officers ran to the camp witness led and called for help. On returning from the camp hes aw Capt. Bull lying unconscious. The sergeant-major made a hasty examination of the captain and saw a severe wound on the right temple and three or four on the head. They took him to camp as quickly as possible. Witness made a superficial post-mortem examination of the body and concluded that death was due to concussion of the brain and sunstroke.

Dr. Nolan was then called and stated that in his report he had said that the wounds were caused by violent blows with a blunt instrument, but the direct cause of death was heat apoplexy. Capt. Bostock's evidence was consistent with his report.
Dr. Nolan stated that, after hearing the evidence, he concluded that death was due to heat apoplexy aggravated by concussion of the brain caused by blows.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN.
div.p: The heavy rains are beginning to show signs in the mountains on the Suakin-Athera line and El Kaimakam Longfield Bey, R.E., chief engineer and assistant director of railways, is taking precautionar measures to cope with them, as last year's wash-outs have taught the railways a good lesson. Bimbashi Ali Eff. Shawki has inspected the whole of the line from Atbara to Suakin, and it is hoped that no damage will be done to the linet his year, especially as so many bridges and culverts have been put down this year.
Mr. Kerr, Acting Governor Red Sea Provinces, has arrived here from Erkoweit to examine some important cases both here and at Port Sudan. He will return to Erkoweit in a few days.
The hot weather has now "come to stay" at Suakin. The hot winds and sandstorms are almost unbearable.

div.head: HELLENIC CONSULATE-GENERAL
div.p: Advices from Athens report that M. Naoum, first dragoman of the Hellenic Legation in Constantinople, is the most probable candidate for the post of Hellenic Consul General in Egypt, which has been rendered vacant by the recall of M. Gennadis.
M. Naoum is, it is true, a foreign subject, but in virtue of the new law concerning dragomans in the service of the Hellenic Government, M. Naoum can easily become a naturalised Hellenic subject.

The Athens "Acropolis," speaking of the probable appointment of M. Naoum, dwells upon the valuable services rendered by that diplomatist as assistant delegate at the negotiations for the conclusion of the Treaty of Peace and the Consular Convention with the Turkish Government. M. Naoum was also one of the delegates for the conclusion of the Turko-Hellenic Commercial Convention. In conclusion, the "Acropolis" alludes to the judgment and diplomatic tact displayed by M. Naoum in the negotiations for a commercial arrangement with Egypt.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: The regulations concerning the use and occupation of public thoroughfares by individuals have been applied by degree to the town of ghirgeh, to date from July 15, and to Luxor to date from the 1st inst.

The Austrian Lloyd packet, which arrived at Alexandria from Brindsi this morning, did not bring the mails from London, which had probably been delayed on land. They may arrive to-morrow by the French steamer or on Wednesdday by the Brindisi mail, but the postal authorities have no definite information on the subject.

The vocal and instrumental concert given at the Casino yesterday afternoon was a great success. The terrace of the Casino presented a most animated aspect; over 4,000 persons being present to listen to an excellent programme. Signa. Levy, a very fine soprano, gave an admirable rendering of 'Vissi 'Arte" from Tosca, which she was obliged to repeat, and duet from Cavalleria Rusticana with Sig. Battain, who possesses a very pleasing tenor voice.

div.head: TALOUDI RELIEVED.
MAGNIFICENT MARCH.
OLD CENTRE OF MAHDISM LOYAL.
div.p: We are glad to be able to inform our readers of the complete success of the column under Miralai O'Connell Bey, Moudir of Kordoan, which left for Taloudi towards the end of last month.

The column was composed of 350 men of the Camel Corps and 200 Sudanese infantry drawn from the garrisons of El Obeid and Bars. Its task was extremely arduous. It had to march over 250 miles through districts which ahd been converted into quagmires by the heavy rains. The men were often up to their necks in water, and how transport animald and especially camels, could have been brought through these sloughs passes the understanding. None the less the column struggled on and finally reached and relieved Taloudi on June 12.

The survivors of the garrison of 100 men reported that after the attack made on them by Arabs during a "diluks," or native dance, in which two officers and 40 men were killed, they had held out in their zeribs and repulsed several attacks. Meantime the Nubas of the hill and several Baggara clans of the district attacked the rebels, who eventually retierd to Jebel Illiri, a mountain S.E. of Talondi, which has for long been the haunt of criminals and broken men of every tribe.

these banditti made common cause with the rebels of Taloudi, but must now repent their folly. The Moudir of Kordofan with his force immediately attacked and stormed their stronghold, thus disposing of both the Taloudi rebels and the outlaws of teh Illiri mountain. 350 of the enemy perished, 100 prisoners were taken, and their complete overthrow made it possible for the Government to send back a squadron of Sudanese cavalry which had been dispatched from Shendi to Kaka, on the White Nile, to co-operate, if necessary, with the western column.

The causes of the outbreak are still obscure but O'Connell Bey denies the rumor that reached Khartoum via Kodok that it had been provoked by the misconduct of Egyptian officers towards the Arab women of the district. In his opinion -- and there is every reason to trust his knowledge of Kordofan and its tribes, -- the Taloudi Arabs, who had long been wont to raid and enslave the unfortunate Nubas of the neighbouring mountains, viewed the establishment of a Government at Taloudi with bitter hostility and resolved to rid themselves of it at the first opportunity.

A very satisfactory feature of this brillian little campaign is the attitude of the great majority of teh tribes of Southern Kordofan. Nubars and Arabs alike opposed the rebels and the people of Jebel Gedir, the first Mahdist centre in the country, where Mohamed Ahmed of Dongola remained after leaving Abba island in 1881 and where the Kawakla tribe possessed a famous and holy stone on which the Prophet Mohamed is said to have sat and prayed, showed themselves aboslutely loyal.
The new Government has evidently won the respect of large sections of the Sudanese, -- a repsect that will be considerably enhanced by the news of its latest victory.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The death of the wife of Marshal Ahmed Mukhtar Pachs, Ottoman High Commissioner in Egypt, occurred at his Excellency's villa at Kizil Toprak, near Constantinople. The funeral, which was very largely attended, took place on the 19th inst. and teh remains were buried in the precincts of the Faith Mosque in Stamboul.
Crookshank Pacha and Mrs. Crookshank leave Port Said for Europe on the 26th inst. per P. & O. S.S. China.
Colonel G.J. Cuthbert, A.A.G., came down to Alexandria from Cairo yesterday.
Lieut. Colonel O.R.O. Ludlow, Officer commaning A.S.C. in Egypt, went to Chibin-el-Kom from Cairo on Saturday.

Lieut. the Hon. C.M. Hore Ruthven, D.S.O, the Black Watch (Royal Highlanders) having been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army from 8th May 1906, with the rank of Bimbashi. He has been posted to the 16th Battalion.

The following offiers has been granted leave of absence, on private affairs: Lieut. Col. W. M. Duckett, A.P.C., Lieut. D.J.C.E. Sherlock, "U" Battery, R.H.A, Lieut. R.b. Otter-Barry, 2nd Royal Sussex Regiment, Captain C.F. Hawley, Captain H. W. H. Bircham, Lieut. H.C.M. Porter, Lieut. R.F. Dalrymple, Lieut. B. Seymour, 2nd-Lieut A. M. Saunders, 2nd-Lieut. J.G. Hargreaves, 1st K.R.R Corps, 2nd-Lieut. E.V. Knox, 1st Royal Dublin Fusiliers.
M. N. Vassiliaded has been authorised to practise as a chemist in Egypt.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.byline: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair-play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits - free discussion.
div.head: ENGLISHMAN'S NIGHT ADVENTURE.
div.byline: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"
div.p: Sir, -- Your readers will, for the most part, concur in the concluding observations of your comment on the pathetic relation by a Cairo correspondent of "Our Englishman's" midnight misadventure in search of adventure after dining, it must be supposed, not wisely however well, winding up by crossing the Rubicon. But the preface convicting the Secret Police of having "grossly exceeded their powers," seems scarcely justified in your correspondent's story of the mishap.

Had "our Englishman" paid attention at school to his classics, he would not have failed to remember the Latin dietum, "Mens tuum negotium;" indicating the only safe course to outsiders when thieves are being looked after in dark corners by the constituted authorities.

He would have borne in mind, too, another classical adage, "Mens tuus oculus," useful to, and intended for, over-curious persons in search of midnight adventures. From "our Englishman's" interest in the capture by the guardians of public safety of the "native lady," there is left a faint suspicion that the attraction which led to his headlong chase after the police in a "hantour" from the English Church to the Telegraph Office, was the exciting prospect of witnessing some fray in which the "negotium" of the police might be women's instead of men's.

Wittingly or Unwittingly, "our Englishman” seems to have done his levels best to associate himself with the deeds of darkness of the malefactor who so indignantly repundiated the honour of his acquaintance at the caracol.

There is a tinge of ingratitude, too, in complaining of the kind privilege accorded him of being alluded to drive in his own hired carriage, albeit at his own expense, accompanied by a special escort, instead of being conveyed to the police station in 'Black Maria" at the expense of the Egyptian Government, according to a practice less suited to the dignified position of "our Englishman.”

There is an aphorism of French origin, "Save me from my friends not borne in mind by your correspondent in giving evidence, that the "peppery individual” in whose behalf he demands ‘‘complete satisfaction for this outrage” on a victim of his own "legitimate curiosity,” 'soundly rated the whole assembly” at the police caracol (we can easily imagine the language in which a proficient in kitchen Arabic and Italian would express himself). This, as you say, in London or Paris, would have ensured him a night's lodging for the remaining hours, under bars and bolts, to be followed, next day, by a suitable fine from police magistrate.

div.head: BATHING AT ALEXANDRIA.
TO THE EDITOR OF "THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
div.p: Sire,—With reference to your interesting article on "The Bathing Season," I should like to point out that the subsidiary precautions which you suggest, such as provision of boats, etc., will be quite ineffectual to make the Alexandria-Ramleh coast a safe resort for bathing, unless something is done to protect the port and bays along the coast from the heavy seas by means of breakwaters. As long as the quays from Kait Bey to Gebel Silsila are exposed to the sea swept under N. W., N. and N.B. gales, not only can nothing in the way of promenade piers or bathing places be established in that port, but even the quay itself stands in danger of being demolished by a high sea. What should be done is to construct a breakwater between Kait Bey Point and Silsila Point on the line of shoals which exists between these points. Such a breakwater could, I understand, be constructed for about L.E. 50,000, enclosing a calm-water space for boating, bathing, etc., of some 2,000 acres. The rent and fees which would be obtained would in a short period re-coup the Municipality for the expenditure incurred. Something similar might be done to convert Stanley Bay into a safe bathing and boating place, and perhaps at other points along the coast. Alexandria would then possess boating and bathing accommodation worthy of its position as the largest seaport in the Eastern Mediterranean — Yours etc.,

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Congo, from MArseilles, passed the STraits of Messina on Saturday, and is due at Alexandria to morrow morning.
Th Ellerman S.S. Fabian sailed on Saturday for Liverpool via Tunis.
